Datatable.LocalizationPair: Endless Space 2: Awakening

Endless Space 2’s fourth expansion brings a brand new faction to the Endless Universe: the Nakalim. A once-vast galactic empire that fell into decline when their gods, the Lost, were slain, this ancient race of devout explorers dreams of the day when those same gods return. The fact that they have been reawakened means half of their prophecy has come true. And the rest . . . ?

The Nakalim are the remains of an advanced starfaring race, and as such they retain much of their old skills and knowledge. Their science has atrophied, however, so to unlock technologies and sciences they must uncover the ancient places and relics that can return the power they once had. Led by a young, impulsive queen who was thrust into power when her parents did not awaken, the struggle between the young and the old, the ancient and the new, will determine their future.

Endless Space 2: Awakening introduces the Nakalim playable Major faction as well as the Academy Empire. You will now be able to interact and negotiate directly with Isyander. As his grand plan begins to unfold and rumors of the Lost begin to circulate, the Academy is set to take a more active role in the future of the galaxy.

Nakalim

The Nakalim developed on a dry planet towards the end of the reign of the Endless. Their reverence for the Lost made them an enemy of the Endless, but the Endless were too wrapped up in their civil war to worry about the Nakalim. Once the Endless fell, they were largely alone in a tamed and civilized galaxy full of the Endless's infrastructure. As result they grew so rapidly that they over-expanded, and the survivors were driven into hibernation--to wait for their prophecy of the Lost to come to pass.

The royal family of the Nakalim--your family--have ruled this empire since its inception. Worshipers of the Lost, they thrived and expanded under the benevolent guidance of a Lost they called Sobra, who had formed a loose Dyson structure around their planet. The murder of their god by the Endless, however, followed by scarcity and decline, drove them into a period of hibernation. Xirmisala

The Xirmisala are a people both ancient and unfortunate. Bioengineers of the Concrete Endless discovered these Dust-sensitive ungulates, and over time they altered the species to make them even more attuned to the presence and movement of Dust. When the Dust Wars started, therefore, the Xirmisala became critical to the war effort, and the Concretes exponentially increased their augmentation efforts. It was quite a success, as the Xirmisala abetted the Endless pogrom that led to the destruction of the Lost. After the Lost fell they evolved on their own, but it was not long before they were discovered by the expanding empire of the Nakalim. Appreciating their skills, the Nakalim adopted the Xirmisala for a different reason: to seek out, against all hope, any Lost that may remain alive in the galaxy.

Morya Kupas

It is unlikely that there is a living Nakalim who has not heard of Kupas. Perhaps the oldest living Nakalim, her role as warrior for the church of Sobra has kept her going through generations of exploration and discovery of relics of the Lost and the Endless. In broadcasts, archaeological digs, and battlefields, she carries her faith like a weapon. For centuries her heart has burned with the injustice and outrage of the Day of the Blasphemy; the day that the Lost were first drawn to the Lodestones and butchered. A fearless, driven, stressful superior officer, she will not stop until the Lost return.
Panako Nakatug

Born ages ago when the empire was at its apogee, Nakatug's service in the security forces of the Remembrance of Sobra church and later for the empire gained him fame as well as a fearsome reputation for precision and perfection. Enhanced by Dust over a period of decades due to his proximity to relics, his evolution into a Hero was a surprise even to himself. Eagerly accepting study at the Academy--an organization whose existence was predicted by the Sobratic Prophecies--he carried his attention to detail and relentless pursuit of perfection into his new role. Often fooled by his ancient and corrupt person, his colleagues soon learn Nakatug is a keen-eyed taskmaster.
Nakatuon

Having passed millennia of hibernation in solo contemplation of the most efficient ways of committing assassination, Nakatuon was thoroughly disoriented when, upon awakening, it found its mind coupled to all the other Remnants in existence. Their new purpose, as defined by Belcus Akad-Talar, was to build a better galaxy for the most deserving species—a contradiction to everything it believed. Roaming from system to system, it pondered. Surely if the Remnants’ creators, the Endless, had made them killing machines, then that is what they should remain? Unless… unless this change of purpose meant that the Endless were perhaps not the benevolent overlords they had seemed to be. Nakatuon was still trying to make up its mind when it came across a Nakalim evangelical mission. They helped it understand this new view of the world and how things came to be, and now, Nakatuon has adjusted its mission to coincide with that of its new friends…
Yr Mel Kara

As many Kal'Tik'Ma explorers, Mel began her life hunting for their lost home planet--covertly, not overtly. After all, who would pay to fund hopeless expeditions to lost stars? With time and experience she saw more, did more, and learned more, becoming Dust-enhanced by accident while seeking ancient Endless star charts in an abandoned asteroid outpost. Still, the sense of loss never left her. Meeting the Nakalim, who sympathized with her plight, she grew over time to adopt their religion and become a fervent believer. After all, to hope that the gods return seems to be as unlikely an event as to hope to find a dead planet around a ruined star... Though Mel is now a seeker of greater things, she still hopes to find, one day, within the wisdom of the relics, a key to the past of her people.

Chapter 1. A Proud Past - Part 1

I have not only lived through a prophecy, I have opened my eyes in wonder and seen it happen before me.
This is my story. I am Marusia, of the royal Mapagna family, princess of the Nakalim. ----- Our sleep was one of desperation. When Sobra was taken from us, when the Endless destroyed the gods, our civilization fell into decline. Centuries of growth and exploration descended into ruin and confusion in a matter of years; our vast galactic empire crumbled until the Nakalim, at risk of chaos and collapse, were driven into hibernation. Many were almost glad to do it, for a prophecy said this: " . . . the sleep of the faithful will be long, and the galaxy will change, and the stars shift in their places; yet in the end, when the time of the Rebirth is near, the faithful shall be awakened by a prophet . . ." There is more to it, as it was a prophecy, and they often go on like that.
Little did we imagine that this prophet would come with tales not only of the treachery of the Endless (as if we did not know), but of a great Tabernacle built to assuage their guilt and to beg the Lost for forgiveness, and of a new and glorious purpose for him and his followers. Most call it simply the Academy, but he whispered to us its full name: The Ultimate Academy of Truth and Repentance. Now we are awake and alive, a reinvigorated people filled with a sense of purpose. But though I am glad to feel the sun upon my face once more, my first act will be to lay my parents to rest, for the long hibernation was too much for their aging bodies. So my story begins at a time of wonder, and prophecy, and loss.

Chapter 2. A Fraught Future - Part 1

It is difficult, sometimes, to tell the difference between outright treason and simple ignorance. ----- This is a situation that I did not expect. The population is not just "grumbling", not just "unhappy", they are striking and marching over questions of religious piety and propriety! I, queen of the Nakalim, who wears the title of Nakalim Defender, have had my leaderships and my faith called into question!
At this moment, I suppose, my anger matches theirs. Did they think we could rebuild an empire from the pews? Learn how to defend ourselves against new weapons by repeating rituals that date from thousands of years ago? I would have thought it was alien agitators, or foreign spies, but I have spoken with the Nakalim Lords and passed among the congregations.
I did not realize the point to which they seek meaning, or solace, or something solid to cling to in a strange galaxy that they no longer understand. I lose time now, and I must put resources into petty projects that do not advance my cause nor my empire's future.
Though I suppose I should be happy that it is indeed "simple ignorance" . . .

Chapter 3. The Seduction of Hope - Part 1

It seems to me that the willingness of a people to complain about their situation in life is positively correlated to how good it is. ----- The grumbling persists, but for the moment I think the risk of open revolt has lessened. But it is important to note that there is a long, long way between "lessened" and "disappeared". How do I get it there? How do I turn those who are fanatically religious and somewhat loyal into fanatically loyal and somewhat religious? My detractors are still numerous, and obviously I understand why they say what they say. After all, my desire to rebuild our empire could be placed anywhere on the scale from "courageous" to "maniacal", depending on the point of view. But I am hoping to create a master stroke; to settle once and for all the question of who leads and who follows. For my father was head of the Remembrance church, and carried the title "Defender of the Lost". My mother was the queen, the sovereign; "Defender of the People". I have inherited my mother's title with the role. But if I can take my father's title as well, ruling the church and the Nakalim Lords, there would be no force within the empire that could attempt to waylay or derail me. Never before in our history has a single Nakalim held both roles; it would be a first. On the other hand, no other Nakalim monarch has been awakened by a prophet of the Lost from centuries of sleep. I will take those odds.

RETURN OF THE ANCIENTS

The Nakalim are an ancient Empire, highly advanced in science thanks to leeching off the Endless long ago. However, this led to dependency, and slowly but surely they lost every impulse for scientific innovation.

The Nakalim rely on Relics, ancient artifacts that they can study. Possessing Relics provides the science that they can't obtain from planets. The Nakalim can also give Relics to Heroes in order to awaken new powers within.
The Nakalim also have a unique system specialization called Temples. With a Temple they can increase their control over the galaxy.

But beware, having this specialization means that all the Population on the planet will work at the Temple, increasing the area of influence at an increased rate instead of providing the usual resources.
ANCIENT POTENTIAL

Gifted systems will give you a permanent tithe of its resources. The Academy will also reward you with some Relics and other bonuses--and they will still count towards your victory condition.
In addition to your special benefits, having this role allows you access to control its unique signature ship, for a price.

Sobra

The Nakalim have been on Sobra since their birth, and though it is heavily exploited they still view it as a gracious and civilized home. A more interesting fact is that the planet was once protected by a Lost, also called Sobra by the Nakalim, who guided and aided them over the long, slow growth of their culture. They feel the loss of their god to the weapons of the Endless keenly, and are dedicated enemies of that dead civilization. From Sobra they once built an empire that controlled much of the galaxy, and they are eager to rebuild it.

Neither. The greatest military thinker of the Academy was a Hissho named Kochita, who looked at conflict from the lenses of space and time. A deep thinker and perhaps the galaxy's greatest strategist, his writings on power, development, diplomacy, and influence remain the most respected bibliography in all of the Academy's many libraries.

We do not know all the details. What we understand is that the Dust crystal, which provided power to the ship, was also deeply impregnated with the knowledge of the Endless. We suspect that this was drawn from the vast Endless complex that was pillaged by the survivors of the Mezari ship "Success". The crystal exploded, and the Dust was released, causing a vast sympathetic reverberation in Dust across the galaxy. It seems that the knowledge buried within the crystal was released, seeding--and accelerating--the scientific advances of nascent civilizations. Our research continues...

This is a question that we do not treat lightly out of both faith and respect. From the point of view of mortals they were gods, though a more technical answer would be "sentient volumes of primordial Dust". They had little purpose other than curiosity, discovery, and play. Many of the great and strange natural wonders of the galaxy are likely artifacts of Lost inquisitiveness. But their physical value in Dust was immense, and the Endless took it upon themselves to butcher them for short-term gain.

During the course of their scientific researches, the Endless learned to harness the gamma rays of dying stars and gravitational anomalies in the galaxy. While the ritual of contact and greeting at the Lodestones was likely seen by the Lost as quaint and amusing, out of curiosity and affection many of them would voluntarily make contact. On the Day of Blasphemy, gamma energy and gravitational disruption was used to capture them and draw the Dust from their forms. Little is known of how or where the Endless developed this technology, as it seems that those who left the Tabernacle of Remorse went to great lengths to destroy the knowledge.
